title: Fears of major flooding as Britain is battered by heavy rain
text:
A slow-moving band of heavy rain set to drench parts of the UK has triggered weather warnings and flood alerts (Picture: PA)

Heavy rain currently sweeping across the country could see much of England flooded in the coming hours, the Met Office has said.

Forecasters warned that more than two inches of rain could fall within 12 hours on Monday in some parts of the country.

A yellow weather warning stretching from Devon on the south coast to South Yorkshire between 12 midday and midnight tomorrow has been issued.

Cities including Manchester, Birmingham, Nottingham, Oxford, London and Portsmouth are within the warning area and are expected to face severe disruption.

The Met Office said the wet weather will move northwards across much of England on Monday, with the heaviest rain forecast for the afternoon and evening.

While up to 25mm is likely to fall ‘quite widely’ some areas could see more than two inches of rain, the Met Office said.

Forecasters warn this could bring flooding and disruption but admitted the situation remains ‘unstable’.

📡 Latest radar 📡 Heavy #rain is spreading north and east this afternoon ☔️ pic.twitter.com/xbRDtlcVvj — Met Office (@metoffice) October 13, 2019

The wet weather will follow an ‘unsettled’ Sunday across England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

Heavy rain is forecast for the Midlands, northern England and Northern Ireland, with some areas seeing up to 20mm fall throughout the day.

Meanwhile, gusts of around 20mph to 30mph are forecast for East Anglia and the North East coast.

Met Office meteorologist Mark Wilson said: ‘It is looking pretty unsettled.

‘Heavy rain across England, Wales and Northern Ireland will push northwards throughout the day.

‘We have not got any weather warnings out [for Sunday], but the rain could cause [road] surface spray, so that could lead to some difficult driving conditions.’

Flooding after persistent heavy rain in Alum Rock, Birmingham, could be repeated in the next 24 hours (Picture: PA)

Heavy rain over the last 24 hours in Essex has caused roads to flood with a severe warning in place for Monday (Picture: Stephen Huntley/HVC)

Mr Wilson said the wet weather will push north throughout the day into southern Scotland.

It will be followed by drier weather moving up from the South and South West from the mid-afternoon.

South-east England is forecast to see the warmest temperatures at 18°C, while the north of England will see the coolest temperatures – between 11°C and 12°C.

Mr Wilson said the rain will ‘ease’ overnight on Sunday and will be followed by fog patches across England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

Despite more wet weather on Monday, Mr Wilson said there is an ‘improving picture’ for Tuesday, with temperatures reaching up to 16°C.

He said while there will be some rain in Northern Ireland on Tuesday, it will be ‘drier’ for the rest of the UK.
